--- "Kent Beck" <kentb@e...> wrote:
> I see what you mean. However, one of our goals in JUnit 4
> was to remove the recursive composition of tests. It is
> difficult to explain and difficult to support properly in
> test runners. What I need is an example of JUnit 4-style
> dynamic test case creation.

Man; I've been cursing JBuilder for several years for its complete 
lack of 'suite' method support!  I can do data-driven tests without 
it, but doing so pretty much destroys the value of Assert methods; I 
must dump all the failures to System.err, and fail a summary.

Examples:

Say I'm writing a few "sort" routines, to be used in different 
cases.  Let's start with a simplistic bubble sort.  I write some 
tests and get BubbleSort implemented.  Now I want to write an 
InsertionSort.  First, I'd like to reuse all the existing tests, 
with an InsertionSort object.  How can I do this when *THE TOOL* has 
complete control over what tests get run, meaning that I have *NO 
CONTROL* over it?!?!?

Pretty much the same story for testing interfaces:
I'd like to write a TestCase child class, with all the tests for an 
interface.  Then for every implementer, I'll say "run all the tests 
in that TestCase class, but use this data (this implementation) for 
testing."  For one thing, this means I'm customizing TestSuite to 
pass parameters to the constructors.

The "suite" method is the escape valve for everything JUnit can't do 
by itself.  Don't take it away from us!
